frontmatter.title: Fortran - ARM 64-Bit Platform - Divide Two Integers

children.value: In this section we will be disassembling simple binaries generated by the Fortran high-level language compiled for the 64-bit ARM platform.
Project code for this section is contained in my

program div_int

        implicit none

        integer         :: a, b, c

        a = 10
        b = 5

        c = a / b

end program div_int
The program displays the contents of the program
. The program creates three integers: a, b, and c.
is assigned the value of 2, and
is assigned the result of the operation
The program is obviously very simple, with no inputs and outputs. The idea is to generate the binary and look at the disassembly to learn about the workings of the 64-bit ARM processor platform.

The chosen test system is my trusty Samsung Chromebook Plus V2, which has a 64-bit ARMv8 processor. This is a very convenient platform for this exercise due to its availability and ease of access from multiple remote systems via SSH.
The program is compiled with the GNU Fortran compiler,
, which is available on the ARM platform. The program is compiled with debugging information using the
option, which allows us to debug the program in GDB and see the source code interspersed with the assembly instructions.
For general edification, we also have
option, an object file with the
option, and object dumps of the object and executable files.
The generic assembly is generated by using the
The object file is generated by using the
The objdump files are generated by using the following command and options:

$ objdump -x -D -S -s -g -t div_int.o > objdump_of_dot_o.txt
$ objdump -x -D -S -s -g -t div_int_Fortran_aarch64_ggdb3 > objdump_of_dot_exe.txt
A rundown of the objdump options is shown here:

$objdump 
Usage: objdump <option(s)> <file(s)>
 Display information from object <file(s)>.
 At least one of the following switches must be given:
  -a, --archive-headers    Display archive header information
  -f, --file-headers       Display the contents of the overall file header
  -p, --private-headers    Display object format specific file header contents
  -P, --private=OPT,OPT... Display object format specific contents
  -h, --[section-]headers  Display the contents of the section headers
  -x, --all-headers        Display the contents of all headers
  -d, --disassemble        Display assembler contents of executable sections
  -D, --disassemble-all    Display assembler contents of all sections
      --disassemble=<sym>  Display assembler contents from <sym>
  -S, --source             Intermix source code with disassembly
      --source-comment[=<txt>] Prefix lines of source code with <txt>
  -s, --full-contents      Display the full contents of all sections requested
  -g, --debugging          Display debug information in object file
  -e, --debugging-tags     Display debug information using ctags style
  -G, --stabs              Display (in raw form) any STABS info in the file
  -W, --dwarf[a/=abbrev, A/=addr, r/=aranges, c/=cu_index, L/=decodedline,
              f/=frames, F/=frames-interp, g/=gdb_index, i/=info, o/=loc,
              m/=macro, p/=pubnames, t/=pubtypes, R/=Ranges, l/=rawline,
              s/=str, O/=str-offsets, u/=trace_abbrev, T/=trace_aranges,
              U/=trace_info]
                           Display the contents of DWARF debug sections
  -Wk,--dwarf=links        Display the contents of sections that link to
                            separate debuginfo files
  -WK,--dwarf=follow-links
                           Follow links to separate debug info files (default)
  -WN,--dwarf=no-follow-links
                           Do not follow links to separate debug info files
  -L, --process-links      Display the contents of non-debug sections in
                            separate debuginfo files.  (Implies -WK)
      --ctf[=SECTION]      Display CTF info from SECTION, (default `.ctf')
      --sframe[=SECTION]   Display SFrame info from SECTION, (default '.sframe')
  -t, --syms               Display the contents of the symbol table(s)
  -T, --dynamic-syms       Display the contents of the dynamic symbol table
  -r, --reloc              Display the relocation entries in the file
  -R, --dynamic-reloc      Display the dynamic relocation entries in the file
  @<file>                  Read options from <file>
  -v, --version            Display this program's version number
  -i, --info               List object formats and architectures supported
  -H, --help               Display this information
We will now disassemble this program on the 64-bit ARM platform and step through the assembly instructions.
When we look at the executableâ€™s objdump, we notice that there are two functions of interest, one is
. The Fortran compiler sets up the program arguments and options in
, while the actual program is contained within
(that is capital MAIN followed by two underscores).
The following text from the executableâ€™s objdump illustrates this:

Disassembly of section .text:

0000000000000814 <MAIN__>:
program div_int
 814:	d10043ff 	sub	sp, sp, #0x10

        implicit none

        integer         :: a, b, c

        a = 10
 818:	52800140 	mov	w0, #0xa                   	// #10
 81c:	b9000fe0 	str	w0, [sp, #12]
        b = 5
 820:	528000a0 	mov	w0, #0x5                   	// #5
 824:	b9000be0 	str	w0, [sp, #8]

        c = a / b
 828:	b9400fe1 	ldr	w1, [sp, #12]
 82c:	b9400be0 	ldr	w0, [sp, #8]
 830:	1ac00c20 	sdiv	w0, w1, w0
 834:	b90007e0 	str	w0, [sp, #4]

end program div_int
 838:	d503201f 	nop
 83c:	910043ff 	add	sp, sp, #0x10
 840:	d65f03c0 	ret

0000000000000844 <main>:
 844:	a9be7bfd 	stp	x29, x30, [sp, #-32]!
 848:	910003fd 	mov	x29, sp
 84c:	b9001fe0 	str	w0, [sp, #28]
 850:	f9000be1 	str	x1, [sp, #16]
 854:	f9400be1 	ldr	x1, [sp, #16]
 858:	b9401fe0 	ldr	w0, [sp, #28]
 85c:	97ffffa5 	bl	6f0 <_gfortran_set_args@plt>
 860:	90000000 	adrp	x0, 0 <_init-0x660>
 864:	91248001 	add	x1, x0, #0x920
 868:	528000e0 	mov	w0, #0x7                   	// #7
 86c:	97ffff9d 	bl	6e0 <_gfortran_set_options@plt>
 870:	97ffffe9 	bl	814 <MAIN__>
 874:	52800000 	mov	w0, #0x0                   	// #0
 878:	a8c27bfd 	ldp	x29, x30, [sp], #32
 87c:	d65f03c0 	ret
. The compiler has translated the Fortran code into assembly with associated runtime setup.
Hereâ€™s the original Fortran code that the assembly represents:

program div_int
  implicit none
  integer :: a, b, c

  a = 10
  b = 5
  c = a / b
end program div_int

children.label: Function: MAIN__ (Entry point for Fortran program)

children.value: on the stack for local variables
is loaded with the immediate value

828:	b9400fe1 	ldr	w1, [sp, #12]    // load `a` into w1
82c:	b9400be0 	ldr	w0, [sp, #8]     // load `b` into w0
830:	1ac00c20 	sdiv	w0, w1, w0       // w0 = w1 / w0  â†’ a / b
834:	b90007e0 	str	w0, [sp, #4]     // store `c` at sp+4
Stores result to stack at offset

838:	d503201f 	nop               // no operation
83c:	910043ff 	add	sp, sp, #0x10   // restore original stack pointer
840:	d65f03c0 	ret               // return
Stack pointer restored to pre-function state.
(Startup entry point for the whole program)

children.label: Function: main (Startup entry point for the whole program)

children.value: This is the C-style entry point that initializes the Fortran runtime and calls

844:	a9be7bfd 	stp	x29, x30, [sp, #-32]!   // push frame pointer and return address
848:	910003fd 	mov	x29, sp                 // set frame pointer
Reserves space for local variables and stores

84c:	b9001fe0 	str	w0, [sp, #28]  // argc
850:	f9000be1 	str	x1, [sp, #16]  // argv

854:	f9400be1 	ldr	x1, [sp, #16]     // load argv
858:	b9401fe0 	ldr	w0, [sp, #28]     // load argc
85c:	97ffffa5 	bl	6f0 <_gfortran_set_args@plt>
to pass arguments to the Fortran runtime.

860:	90000000 	adrp	x0, 0 <_init-0x660>      // get page address (base of .rodata or symbol region)
864:	91248001 	add	x1, x0, #0x920           // x1 = x0 + 0x920
868:	528000e0 	mov	w0, #0x7                 // runtime options bitmask
86c:	97ffff9d 	bl	6e0 <_gfortran_set_options@plt>
The values suggest setting I/O or floating-point behavior.

874:	52800000 	mov	w0, #0x0          // return code 0
878:	a8c27bfd 	ldp	x29, x30, [sp], #32  // restore frame and return address
87c:	d65f03c0 	ret
This disassembly corresponds to a minimal Fortran program that:
Sets up the Fortran runtime environment via
Let me know if youâ€™d like the equivalent C version, annotated binary layout, or memory map!

This disassembly shows the machine code for a simple Fortran program compiled for the AArch64 (ARM64) architecture, likely using gfortran (GNU Fortran compiler). The Fortran source, embedded in the disassembly, is a program named â€œdiv_intâ€ that declares three integers (
(integer division, resulting in 2), and ends without any output or I/O. Itâ€™s essentially a trivial computation with no side effects.
The code is split into two functions:
: The mangled name for the Fortran main program body. It handles variable allocation, assignments, the division, and cleanup.
: The actual entry point, generated by the compiler for runtime setup. It interfaces with the GNU Fortran runtime library (libgfortran) to handle command-line arguments and options, calls

The code uses stack storage for variables (no register optimization, suggesting unoptimized compilation like -O0). Instructions include hexadecimal offsets, opcodes, mnemonics, and operands. Some calls use the Procedure Linkage Table (PLT) for dynamic linking to external functions (e.g., from libgfortran). Relocations or PLT stubs (like
AArch64 conventions: 64-bit registers (x0-x31), 32-bit views (w0-w31), stack pointer (sp) grows downward, little-endian memory. Integers are 32-bit (4 bytes each), so stack slots are 4 bytes.
Iâ€™ll break it down instruction-by-instruction, linking to the Fortran source.
This is the core of the Fortran program. It allocates 16 bytes on the stack (for
plus alignment padding), assigns values, performs signed integer division, stores the result, and deallocates before returning.

Subtract 0x10 (16 decimal) from sp to allocate stack space. This reserves room for three 4-byte integers (12 bytes) plus 4 bytes for 16-byte alignment (AArch64 ABI mandates this). Corresponds to entering
Move immediate 0xa (10 decimal) into w0 (32-bit register). Prepares
Store w0 (10) to memory at [sp + 12]. Assigns to
= 10) into w1. Loads first operand for
= 5) into w0. Now w1 = a, w0 = b.
Signed divide w1 (a) by w0 (b), store quotient in w0. Computes 10 / 5 = 2 (integer division; remainder discarded).
is for signed integers (Fortran integers are signed). If b=0, this would trap (division by zero), but here b=5.
No operation. Compiler-inserted padding for alignment or to separate code sections. Marks end of computation before
Add 0x10 to sp, deallocating stack space. Cleans up variables.
Return by jumping to address in x30 (link register, set by caller). Exits
translates the Fortran directlyâ€”stack alloc, load constants, divide, store, dealloc. No optimizations; all via stack.
This is the program entry point, handling Fortran runtime initialization. It saves registers, passes args to libgfortran, sets options, calls
, and exits with status 0. Uses System V ABI (args in x0-x7, etc.).
Store pair: Save x29 (frame pointer) and x30 (link register) to [sp - 32], then sp -= 32. Allocates 32 bytes and preserves caller registers (ABI compliance).
Set x29 to sp. Establishes frame pointer for debugging/unwinding.
Store w0 (argc, command-line arg count from OS) to [sp + 28].
Store x1 (argv, arg pointers) to [sp + 16]. Saves args.
Load argv into x1 (prep for call).
(PLT stub at 0x6f0). Calls libgfortran function with argc (w0) and argv (x1) to initialize Fortran args.
indicates dynamic linking via PLT (Procedure Linkage Table resolves at runtime).
Address relative page: Load page-aligned address (high 21 bits) of a data section into x0. Points to options data (likely in .rodata). The
is a linker note; actual address resolved.
Add 0x920 (2336 decimal) to x0, store in x1. Completes pointer to options array.
Move 0x7 (7) into w0. Likely option count or flags for
(stub at 0x6e0) with count/flags (w0) and options pointer (x1). Sets runtime options (e.g., error handling, floating-point).
Move 0 into w0. Sets exit status (success).
Load pair: Restore x29 and x30 from [sp], then sp += 32. Stack cleanup.
Return to caller (OS/runtime), exiting with w0=0.
bootstraps the Fortran environment via libgfortran, runs the program, and exits cleanly. PLT calls enable shared library use.
